Thank you to everyone who attended the townhall meeting last night and for those who tuned in to the live broadcasts. Over 50 people joined the event in person and over 3,000 watched the live feeds from home. I would call this virtual townhall experiment a success! pic.twitter.com/Nlw9uG3NkV
On Title IV changes: “We must do everything we can to protect men and women who are victims of sexually assault. If we’re erring, we need to be erring on the side of the victims.”

"I think it’s important that we quickly resolve that. The economy is healthy and it’s absorbing these problems, but both of these things introduce uncertainty into the market place, which is what we’re seeing in the stock market.” (2/2)

On the economy: "Utah is resilient, but the economy in the nation is more fragile. Watching the tariffs and the trade war going on; I'm actually more concerned about that impact on the economy than the shutdown." (1/2)

On unpaid, furloughed government workers: “I walked through TSA this morning and I was embarrassed. It’s not a good situation in any way, shape, or form— and that’s why I’m here, working with my colleagues, and searching for the answer myself that ends this."
On the Mueller investigation: "Those that do or do not support the President should want this investigation to be carried through. It’s in our nation’s best interest to be resolved." (2/2)

On the Mueller investigation: "I am waiting, with great anticipation, for Mueller to finish the investigation & give us the facts. The reality is, we have a faction of the information at our fingertips." (1/2)

On the shutdown: “You can blame the President all you want, but this is Congress’ fault. We wouldn’t be here if we’d done our job and funded the government. At the end of the day, Congress has to look in the mirror and say, ‘We own this. This is our fault.’”

"Right now, we don’t have the resources at the border. If you'll remember when 7,000 people showed up, we simply could not process them because we hadn’t invested in our border. We’ve got to put the resources there." (2/2)

On asylum: “People have been asking for a long time for the ability to seek asylum in their own country, so they don’t have to make the dangerous journey up to the border. This would be a good thing." (1/2)

On opioids: "In Utah we lead the country in a statistic we should not be proud of: the highest rate of opioid addictions in pregnant women. That's why I introduced the POPPY study act- to find alternatives we have to pain and treatments." MORE: https://bit.ly/2FJ88lV

On a wall: “Judges, facilities, boots on the ground, technology, all of these have great bipartisan support. Until recently, some type of barrier did have bipartisan support as well. The answer is far broader than a wall. But we as a county must be willing to invest in security."

Curtis on the shutdown: “So far in the shutdown, the different sides have clung to different positions w/o inching over. This puts us in ‘winner takes all’ philosophy. ‘Unless I get my way, I’m not conceding.’ This will never solve anything; there’s got to be some give & take."

ICYMI: Yesterday I introduced the “No Work, No Pay” bill to stop congressional pay during government shutdowns. I strongly believe that Congress should be held accountable to find common ground to solve this funding impasse. https://www.ksl.com/article/46460816/utah-rep-curtis-seeks-to-withhold-congressional-pay-during-government-shutdowns …

As I have done in previous government shutdowns, I have asked the Clerk of the House to withhold my pay until the government reopens. My No Work, No Pay Bill would require this for all Members of Congress #utpol pic.twitter.com/kmNjbxKTMA
https://www.abc4.com/news/politics/representative-curtis-asks-to-go-without-pay-during-shutdown/1685252556 …

The American people expect Congress to do its most basic job: pass a budget and fund the government. If we can’t, then we shouldn’t get paid. Today I introduced H.R. 26, the "No Work, No Pay Act of 2019." My bill would prohibit Congress from being paid during government shutdowns
